creator: bugzilla@spack.org
text:
The documentation says that the list of hosts should be space seperated.  In fact this does NOT work 
and "apachectl configtest will give you an error about it telling you that hosts must be space separated.

In fact the hosts must be *comma* seperated.  This appears to work correctly in all the ways I've been 
able to test.

creator: minfrin@apache.org
text:
Can you include examples of a config that works, and a config that doesn't work?

The URL handling in v2.0.51 is handled by the LDAP library, not httpd or apr,
and is specified by an RFC - which LDAP library are you using?

creator: bugzilla@spack.org
text:
This works:

AuthLDAPURL ldap://ldap1,ldap2/ou=People,dc=example,dc=com?uid?one

This doesn't (not the lack of a comma):

AuthLDAPURL ldap://ldap1 ldap2/ou=People,dc=example,dc=com?uid?one

The Apache documentation here:

http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_auth_ldap.html

Says:

"To  specify multiple, redundant LDAP servers, just list all servers, separated by spaces. mod_auth_ldap  
will try connecting to each server in turn, until it makes a  successful connection."

Which is incorrect based on everything I've been able to test.

I'm using the Debian Linux Apache2 and OpenLDAP packages:

ii  apache2                              2.0.51-2
ii  apache2-common                       2.0.51-2
ii  apache2-mpm-prefork                  2.0.51-2
ii  ldap-utils     2.1.30-2
ii  libldap2       2.1.30-2

Adam.
Sorry where it says "not the lack of comma" it should say "*note* the lack of comma".
creator: bugzilla@spack.org

text:
In httpd v2.0 URL handling is done by the LDAP library, ie in your case OpenLDAP
v2.1.

This is going to take some investigating as to why they changed the URL format,
as my understanding is that this is specified by an RFC.

If you try OpenLDAP v2.2, do you get the same thing?
creator: minfrin@apache.org

text: Sorry I don't currently have the resources to try OpenLDAP 2.2.
creator: bugzilla@spack.org

text:
As far as I can see, OpenLDAP accepts either comma or space as a delimiter, and has done for a couple 
of years at least.

However, at the risk of being obvious, I note that the Apache configuration system uses spaces as 
argument separators, and the AuthLDAPURL takes a single argument.

I would therefore expect either of the following to work (but I haven't actually tried it).

AuthLDAPURL "ldap://ldap1 ldap2/ou=People,dc=example,dc=com?uid?one"
AuthLDAPURL ldap://ldap1,ldap2/ou=People,dc=example,dc=com?uid?one
creator: rici@ricilake.net

text:
I have explicitly tried both and spaces do not work, at least for the combination of packages that I 
listed.  That is why I submitted this bug report. :-)
creator: bugzilla@spack.org

text:
Could you test httpd v2.1 and see if this problem still occurs. (The v2.0 LDAP
code has effectively been abandoned as the fixes have basically been a rewrite,
which can be found in httpd v2.1).

httpd v2.1 now does all URL parsing itself, and so will be consistent on all
platforms. If there is still a problem, please reopen this bug.
creator: minfrin@apache.org
